Introduction Hot extremes and multi-day heatwaves are increasing in frequency, intensity, and per- sistence as the planet warms; even small increments in global mean temperature yield dis- cernible increases in hot-extreme occurrence and severity [1, 2]. For building resilience, the critical question is not performance under an average future slice, but whena design fails under plausible future sequences . We learn sub-daily structure from in-situ station observations via NOAA’s Integrated Surface Database (ISD) [3, 4]. Because the backbone network (ASOS/AWOS) is primarily at airports embedded in urban fabrics, these data offer city-proximal exposure compared with coarse reanalyses [5, 6]. Representativeness and siting follow the Local Climate Zones framework and canonical urban heat-island physics [7, 8]. Future daily-scale signals come from CORDEX, linked to CMIP and designed for im- pacts/adaptation [9, 10]. We adopt these day-by-day signals so that trends and event timing (e.g., hot-spell onset/persistence) are scenario-faithful. Typical-yearweatherfiles(TMY/TWY;IWEC2)smoothextremesandbreakpersistence [11, 12, 13]. Comparative analyses and assessments show material discrepancies versus multi-year actual weather (AWY/AMY) across climates and typologies [14, 15, 16]. Recent community resources (IEA EBC Annex 80) package future TMYs and explicit heat-wave years (HWYs) with multi-year projections [17], which lowers barriers but still emphasizes selected years rather than time-continuous, probability-aware futures. Trend-preserving quantile approaches such as QDM retain projected changes [18], while multivariatemethodssuchasMBCnextendbiascorrectiontojointdistributions[19]; reviews attest to their maturity [20]. Morphing methods are practical for average slices but cannot capture evolving persistence/compound extremes [21]. Most “future weather” workflows in buildings and the grid adopt time-slice files (e.g., 2030s/2050s/2080s) generated by morph- ing or generator approaches. In practice, designers use CIBSE [22] TRY/DSY sets for spe- cific horizons (e.g., TM49 for London[23]) or commercial datasets such as WeatherShift[24]; at the tool level, CCWorldWeatherGen and newer generators operationalize the classic Belcher–Hacker–Powell morphing method [25, 26, 27]. These pipelines doreflect climatologi- calshifts,buttheytypicallyapply delta-change adjustments tohistoricalseries(means/variances, sometimes quantiles) and deliver only a few representative years per horizon rather than a continuous time series—so they can weaken day-to-day joint variability (e.g., Ta–RH–wind covariation), extreme-event continuity, and regime persistence in long stress tests [28, 29]. Our contribution is a year-by-year sAMY sequence (2025–2095) that is GCM/RCM- anchored and bias-corrected to preserve diurnal shape and extreme-event structure, then used tofreeze 2021 capacities and trace energy, comfort, and system-failure regimes con- tinuously. This complements morphing-based tools (e.g., epwshiftr ) and curated future- weather sets from Annex 80 (typical and extreme years for discrete horizons) by adding a continuous timeline and a mechanistic failure analysis (coil-capacity vs controller-struggle) that three-slice workflows cannot expose [30, 31].
